text:
I have a slight contention about the "good writing as table stakes" comment.

The more difficult the topic, the more difficult it is to create content that resonates, teaches, communicates well.

There are TONS of academics out there that know waaaaaay more about, say, multiplexing a quantum computer than I do... but good god try having them write the knowledge out in a way a busy CEO can understand.

I generally agree with the overall sentiment but think there will still be a solid market for writers who can intake SME knowledge and output good content without being the SME themselves. ~ <@UJG9WTEKG>

text:
<@U011UJX75PE> first find me the SMEs! :wink:

From what I vaguely remember, it had to do with stuttering the timing so that the each calculation got caught in a loop somewhere. You pile more and more computations into this "holding area" and this can work for quantum because quantum "space" is fine with all these looping computations piled atop each other. When you finally pull the trigger to get the output, all loops execute at once?

text: I think the core difficulty will be finding the balance between knowledge and writing. In the dev space, for instance, a lot of the content readers want is tutorials but only a real dev (generally) can write a tutorial. But it’s hard to get a real dev to write because writing always pays way less. Hiring freelance devs is one route around this but if marketing teams want technically proficient writers, full time, then they’re going to have to pay up.

elements.text: I think the core difficulty will be finding the balance between knowledge and writing. In the dev space, for instance, a lot of the content readers want is tutorials but only a real dev (generally) can write a tutorial. But it’s hard to get a real dev to write because writing always pays way less. Hiring freelance devs is one route around this but if marketing teams want technically proficient writers, full time, then they’re going to have to pay up.

text: and piggybacking off of what <@UJ2N9A3GT> said, you have to take into account the different _kinds_ of writing at play based on what the content needs to do. Writing to persuade/sell is _very_ different than writing to educate/inform. A technical SME may be able to write well enough to execute straight-up educational content - and fall flat in contexts where the goal is to sell or persuade.

text:
I agree that there's money to be made in specialization. But I disagree that in-house folks will become highly specialized as it limits their career potential.

If I were to specialize in the events industry, I would have been SOL after Eventbrite laid me off at the beginning of the pandemic.

elements.text:
I agree that there's money to be made in specialization. But I disagree that in-house folks will become highly specialized as it limits their career potential.

If I were to specialize in the events industry, I would have been SOL after Eventbrite laid me off at the beginning of the pandemic.

text: The skill that content marketers (and frankly all marketers) need to master is extracting and distilling subject matter expertise — at either a broad or specific level depending on the topic/audience.

elements.text: The skill that content marketers (and frankly all marketers) need to master is extracting and distilling subject matter expertise — at either a broad or specific level depending on the topic/audience.

text: Alan Alda's <https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01M61KNLW/ref=dp-kindle-redirect?_encoding=UTF8&btkr=1|If I Understood You, Would I Have This Look on My Face?> is a great resource on that skill, btw.

elements.text: Alan Alda's
If I Understood You, Would I Have This Look on My Face?
is a great resource on that skill, btw.

text: <@UUH2EB134> I totally agree and to add another dimension to this point, on the agency side, we offer services for technical companies and even with that broad-ish specialization, it’s still hard to be specialized enough. If a startup comes to us with a cutting edge data science product, it doesn’t matter if I know the broad strokes of SQL. I’m not proficient in their very particular niche, meaning I can’t (without the learning you mention) write about it. And, as you say, it would be risky to my career to devote all my time to it.

elements.text: I totally agree and to add another dimension to this point, on the agency side, we offer services for technical companies and even with that broad-ish specialization, it’s still hard to be specialized enough. text:
<@UJ2N9A3GT>'s point sparked another one that's highly relevant.

The half-life of a professional skill is estimated to be between 3-5 years and about 18 months for anything related to software and IT. Thing is, that often cited estimate was from a 2011 study and anyone who's paying attention the last year can sense that half-life shorten.

So being a content marketer with a highly specialized subject matter expertise would require them to be a practitioner who's continuously sharpening (reskilling/upskilling) their capabilities — just so they can continue being an authority on the topic.

text: to use <@UUH2EB134>’s example, i think specializing in the event space is low risk. there is a learning curve, but it's not nearly as steep as SQL which is nothing compared to something like ruby, javsascript, etc. if you dive in and ultimately find it's not something you want to spend years pursuing, you've still learned something quite valuable and know have some SQL skills to supplement existing conetnt skills

text: <@UJG9WTEKG> in my case at least, I want to stick to writing and editing. I know I could get paid much more if I pivoted into development or data but I don’t think that’s where my skills or passion lie. Plus, I’ve grown increasingly skeptical that having broad tech skills are useful in content. The clients I’m seeing don’t care about, for example, broad/shallow SQL knowledge. They want advanced knowledge that complements their super niche products. They want someone on the cutting edge with them.

They want advanced knowledge that complements their super niche products. They want someone on the cutting edge with them.
